Knowledge Point: There is one slot before the subject, three slots between the subject and the object, two between object and predicate, and three after the predicate. Modifiers that occupy the same slot are mutually exclusive, with the exception of slots 6 and 7, where the waters are a bit murky (see comments below). Some slots (2, 6, 7) are not for words, but for dependent morphology only. The template for clausal modification is given in~(\ref{exe:tamplate}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: (\ref{exe:seteba}) and~(\ref{exe:diwatkok}) are taken from a recording where two women sit with different kinds of fishing gear and explain how they (would) use it. In~(\ref{exe:sortam}), someone asks what they should do with their newly caught fish. (\ref{exe:rumasa}) expresses a command and a possible result or consequence. Irrealis =et comes at the end of a breath group.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Irrealis =et is also common in expository texts, where it is usually alternated with predicates that are not marked for irrealis. Consider~(\ref{exe:ramasii}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: \is{conditional}Conditional clauses also make use of irrealis =et on the predicate expressing the condition. They are treated in §\ref{sec:condclause}. Note that volitional =kin, treated in §\ref{sec:kin}, combines with irrealis =et if it is used in its conditional sense, as in~(\ref{exe:saor}). The volitional marker always precedes the irrealis marker.
Content 1: \gll et=at saor=kin=\textbf{et} me isetengamati | \gls canoe=OBJ anchor={\glkin}=IRR TOP big_effort | \glt `[Before], if you wanted to anchor your boat, it was very difficult.'

Knowledge Point: Volitional mood enclitic =kin attaches to the predicate. It is mainly used to express plans and wishes, as well as events that are about to happen. The different uses of =kin are exemplified in~(\ref{exe:kin}) to~(\ref{exe:kin2}). (\ref{exe:kin}) expresses a plan or wish. In~(\ref{exe:kintoni}), the common use of =kin with toni `want' is illustrated.\footnote{It is unclear whether toni `want' can be used without volitional =kin. Toni can also mean `say; think' (§\ref{sec:mvctoni}), so many of the corpus instances of toni followed by a verb that is not marked with =kin are ambiguous between the `want' and the `say; think' reading.} The phrase in~(\ref{exe:kinabout}) is used to describe the twelfth picture in the Family problems picture task \parencite{carroll2009}, where a child is falling out of its mother's arms, and illustrates the prospective use of =kin. (\ref{exe:kin2}) is the first utterance in a text where a woman explains how to make a basket. It can be interpreted as an action that is about to happen (at least in the speaker's mind) or as a plan. \is{prospective} \is{irrealis} \is{mood} \is{volitional}
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: (An example of volitional =kin and irrealis =et can be found in~(\ref{exe:saor}) in §\ref{sec:et}.)
Content 1: \gll et=at saor=kin=\textbf{et} me isetengamati | \gls canoe=OBJ anchor={\glkin}=IRR TOP big_effort | \glt `[Before], if you wanted to anchor your boat, it was very difficult.'

Knowledge Point: In \is{predicate!complex}complex predicates, volitional =kin comes on the last constituent of the predicate and has scope over the entire action or event, such as the construction kuru masara `bring towards land' in~(\ref{exe:botak}).
Content 1: \gll mu se taruo toni mena Botak kiun=at kuru masarat=\textbf{kin} | \gls 3PL IAM say say later Botak wife.3POSS=OBJ bring move_landwards={\glkin} | \glt `They already said that soon Botak will bring his wife.

Knowledge Point: Imperative mood, used for commands, is formed by adding =te (singular, though occasionally used for plural) or =tar (plural\is{plural!verbal}) to the predicate. The subject may be elided. (\ref{exe:meieba}) shows the singular imperative cliticised to the verb kome `look', and~(\ref{exe:metkore}) shows it cliticised to the locative demonstrative metko `there', which functions as the predicate in that clause. Of the locative predicates that are marked with the imperative, it only occurs on those locative predicates that express movement towards a goal, not on locatives that express static \is{location}location (§\ref{sec:loc}). The plural imperative\is{person marking}\is{indexing|see{person marking}} is illustrated in~(\ref{exe:borar}). Imperative =te follows aspectual marker =teba, as in~(\ref{exe:tebare}).
Content 1: \gll nene mei eba kome=\textbf{te} | \gls grandmother come.IMP then look=IMP | \glt `Grandmother come and look!'
Content 2: \gll mu toni ka metko=\textbf{te} | \gls 3SG say 2SG DIST.LOC=IMP | \glt `They said: ``You go there!'''
Content 3: \gll ka marmar=teba=\textbf{te} ka-mun sara=in | \gls 2SG walk={\glteba}=SG.IMP 2SG-PROH ascend=PROH | \glt `You just walk, don't you get up [your bike]!'

Knowledge Point: Directional verbs (which end in -a) and transitive verbs ending in -ma, described in §\ref{sec:dir} and~§\ref{sec:macie}, have imperative forms where final -a is replaced with \mbox{-ei}. For example, bara `go down' has the imperative form barei (example~\ref{exe:barei}) and potma has the imperative form potmei (example~\ref{exe:potmei}). These are also both examples of \is{predicate!complex}complex predicates, which show that the imperative is marked on the second verb, and has scope over the whole construction. An exception is the imperative of mia, which becomes not miei but mei, as in~(\ref{exe:meieba}) above.
Content 1: \gll mena ka nasuat=i \textbf{barei} | \gls then 2SG tuck=PLNK descend.IMP | \glt `Then you tuck down.'
Content 2: \gll ka neba=at era \textbf{potmei} | \gls 2SG PH=OBJ ascend cut.IMP | \glt `You go up and cut a whatsitsname!'
Content 3: \gll nene mei eba kome=\textbf{te} | \gls grandmother come.IMP then look=IMP | \glt `Grandmother come and look!'

Knowledge Point: The plural imperative form of all -n/-t verbs is likely =r. At this point there is evidence from directional verbs like sara `go up', illustrated in~(\ref{exe:sarar}), and other -n/-t verbs such as na `consume' and gocie `to stay', illustrated in~(\ref{exe:nar}) and~(\ref{exe:gocier}), respectively.
Content 1: \gll muap se kalar sara=\textbf{r} o | \gls food IAM ready ascend=PL.IMP EMPH | \glt `The food is ready, come up!'
Content 2: \gll coba ki wat yuwat na=\textbf{r} | \gls try 2PL coconut PROX.OBJ consume=PL.IMP | \glt `You guys try eat this coconut!'
Content 3: \gll kier tumtum karuok=bon gocie=\textbf{r} | \gls 2DU children four=COM stay=PL.IMP | \glt `You two and the four children stay!'

Knowledge Point: Prohibitive mood is expressed with a dedicated construction involving suffix \mbox{-mun} on the pronominal subject and clitic =in on the predicate. (\ref{exe:ewain2}) shows a clause in prohibitive mood with =in on a verbal predicate, and (\ref{exe:koineh}) shows =in on a locative predicate. There is no distinct plural form of the prohibitive. The combination of -mun and negator =nin is ungrammatical.\footnote{Alternatively, one could say that prohibitive =in triggers the use of special prohibitive pronoun forms (since the form -mun only occurs on pronouns).}
Content 1: \gll ka-\textbf{mun} se reidak-i ewa=\textbf{in} | \gls 1SG-PROH IAM much-OBJQNT speak=PROH | \glt `Don't you speak much anymore!'
Content 2: \gll an toni sor-kang me ki-\textbf{mun} gareor=i pasier=ko=\textbf{in} eh | \gls 1SG say fish-bone TOP 2PL-PROH dump=PLNK sea=LOC=PROH TAG | \glt `I said those fish bones, don't you guys dump [them] in the sea!'

Knowledge Point: Other referents than second-person singular may be the subject of prohibition, such as `smoke' in~(\ref{exe:sarein2}). Because -mun cannot be attached to nouns, the noun is preceded by a pronoun. Like in the imperative mood, prohibitive forms of directional verbs and transitive verbs in -ma are different: instead of ending in -a + -in, they become -ein. (\ref{exe:mumun}) illustrates a prohibitive with a third person plural.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: As illustrated in~(\ref{exe:sareinn}), -mun cannot be suffixed to nouns. When using someone's title or name, the pronoun with -mun follows the noun in such a vocative\is{vocative} example, as exemplified in~(\ref{exe:esaproh2}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll \textbf{esa} ka-\textbf{mun} sara=in | \gls father 2SG-PROH ascend=PROH | \glt `Father, don't (you) go up!'

Knowledge Point: When the pronoun is elided, -mun is elided as well, such as in example~(\ref{exe:tin2}).
Content 1: \gll bo kuet=te tik=\textbf{in} | \gls go bring={\glte} be_long=PROH | \glt `Don't [you] bring it for a long time!'

Knowledge Point: Most clausal modifiers are incompatible with the prohibitive. The aspectual particle se `already' (iamitive) and the aspectual word tok `yet; still; first' (\is{nondum}nondum), however, are compatible. The combination of the iamitive se and the prohibitive results in the meaning `not anymore' (i.e. the iamitive has scope over the prohibitive). The nondum tok plus a prohibitive results in the meaning `not yet', illustrated in~(\ref{exe:muntok2}). This is parallel to the meanings of the iamitive and nondum with regular verbal negation\is{negation}, as illustrated in Table~\ref{tab:setok} in §\ref{sec:setok}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The prohibitive may follow a cliticised adverbial such as =sawe(t) `too', as exemplified in~(\ref{exe:pimun}).
Content 1: \gll nasuena bolon-i baran pi-\textbf{mun} talalu pen=\textbf{sawet=in} o | \gls sugar little-OBJQNT descend 1PL.INCL-PROH too sweet=too=PROH EMPH | \glt `[We] put in a little sugar, we shouldn't make it too sweet!'

Knowledge Point: In \is{predicate!complex}complex predicates, it is the last constituent that carries prohibitive =in. It has scope over the whole construction. (\ref{exe:ewainmelelu2}) is a single clause.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: One may combine a prohibitive and an imperative in one message as in~(\ref{exe:melelure2}), which is biclausal as indicated by square brackets.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Conditional mood is made with conditional clitic =o or =ero, which attaches to the predicate with the condition. The condition is followed by a new clause with the consequence. It occurs about ten times in the corpus, and mostly in contexts with several conditions. The two variants of the clitic are given in~(\ref{exe:warobes}) and~(\ref{exe:geroo}). (\ref{exe:geroo}) also shows a negative condition. (\ref{exe:nanere}) shows a possible third variant, =ere, but it occurs only in that utterance. Note that the consequence is expressed as just a predicate in all cases in the corpus. There is not enough data to determine for which types of conditions (e.g. implicative, predictive, indicative, counterfactual) these clitics are used.
Content 1: \gll jadi tanaman pun demekian wat=\textbf{o} bes im=\textbf{o} bes sayang=\textbf{o} bes | \gls so plant even thus coconut=COND good banana=COND good nutmeg=COND good | \glt `So whichever plant [we grow], whether it's coconut, banana or nutmeg, it's good.'
Content 2: \gll ka-tain=a toni ka Tarus-pis=i bo=\textbf{ero} se bot ge=\textbf{ero} ge mu bukan in kat paksa=nin | \gls 2SG-alone=FOC say 2SG Tarus-side=PLNK go=COND IAM go not=COND no INT not 1PL.EXCL 2SG.OBJ force=NEG | \glt `You said yourself if you wanted to go to Tarus, you go, if not, not, we didn't force you.'
Content 3: \gll ka-tain=a toni ka Tarus-pis=i bo=\textbf{ero} se bot ge=\textbf{ero} ge mu bukan in kat paksa=nin | \gls 2SG-alone=FOC say 2SG Tarus-side=PLNK go=COND IAM go not=COND no INT not 1PL.EXCL 2SG.OBJ force=NEG | \glt `You said yourself if you wanted to go to Tarus, you go, if not, not, we didn't force you.'
Content 4: \gll ter nan=\textbf{ere} bisa kai nan=\textbf{ere} bisa | \gls tea consume=COND can medicine consume=COND can | \glt `So [you] can drink it like tea and [you] can drink it like medicine.' [Lit.: `If you drink it like tea, that's possible, if you take it like medicine, that's possible.']

Knowledge Point: Apprehensive mood, used when the speaker wishes to express fear that something bad will happen, is done with an apprehensive clitic =re, which is attached to the subject or object NP of the clause. The predicate is marked with irrealis =et (§\ref{sec:et}), and many clauses are preceded by the \is{interjection}interjection jaga `watch out' (a Malay loan). In contrast to precautionary constructions (§\ref{sec:appreh}), only the danger is expressed and not necessarily the precaution to be taken. This morpheme is not found in the natural speech corpus, but was easily elicited with the help of pictures designed by Marine Vuillermet (p.c.) depicting dangerous situations, or by simply asking speakers what they would say in a specific dangerous situation. Examples of pictures were that of a snake under a chair (example~\ref{exe:kipkader}), or a crocodile approaching a human being. An example of a dangerous situation I described is walking on the beach under palm trees bearing ripe coconuts. In that situation, someone might utter~(\ref{exe:watre}). Note that in this example, the suggested precaution to take is also expressed in an imperative clause preceding the apprehensive clause.
Content 1: \gll jaga eh kip kadera elak-un=ko ma=\textbf{re} kat kararuot=et | \gls watch_out INT snake chair bottom-3POSS=LOC 3SG=APPR 2SG.OBJ bite=IRR | \glt `Watch out, there is a snake under the chair, it might bite you.'
Content 2: \gll ka kolko=te wat=\textbf{re} kat kosarat=et | \gls 2SG move_out=IMP coconut=APPR 2SG.OBJ hit=IRR | \glt `Move aside, or a coconut might hit you!' (or: `Move aside, lest a coconut hit you!')

Knowledge Point: In the previous examples, the apprehensive morpheme =re is attached to the noun that refers to the danger. In intransitive clauses, the danger is the addressee themselves, because they are behaving irresponsibly. In~(\ref{exe:kire}), the speaker utters an imaginary warning to kids jumping from the dock. If they do not jump far enough away from a dock, they might hit sharp rocks.
Content 1: \gll jaga ki=\textbf{re} tur=et eh dalang=i kolko=rar | \gls watch_out 2PL=APPR fall=IRR INT jump=PLNK move_out=IMP.PL | \glt `Watch out or you'll fall, jump away [from the dock].'

Subsubsection: Iamitive se `already' and nondum tok `still; yet; first'\is{iamitive\is{nondum
Knowledge Point: Kalamang has one aspectual particle, se `already', and one aspectual word, tok `still; yet; first'. Both follow the subject NP. Se has an allomorph he, which is usually used after vowels (see §\ref{sec:len}). This is not a watertight rule: one does find se after vowels and (less commonly) he after consonants. This suggests that se/he is developing into a clitic (which attaches to the subject NP). Because the form se or he is not completely predictable from the phonological context, I give both variants as they are found in the corpus examples. I gloss se `already' as \textsc{iam} for iamitive, which are ``more or less grammaticalised markers that have functions shared by `already' and the perfect\is{perfect}'' \parencite[][4]{olsson2013}. (\ref{exe:se1}) and~(\ref{exe:tokstill}) illustrate the syntactic position of se and tok, respectively.
Content 1: \gll pas opa me dudan-mur-un \textbf{se} mat panok∼panok | \gls woman {\glopa} TOP cousin-KIN.PL-3POSS IAM 3SG.OBJ order∼RED | \glt `That woman, her cousins already ordered him.'
Content 2: \gll sayang-un \textbf{tok} kalom{\textless}lom{\textgreater}un | \gls nutmeg-3POSS still young{\textless}RED{\textgreater} | \glt `Their nutmeg is still young.'

Subsubsection: Iamitive se `already' and nondum tok `still; yet; first'\is{iamitive\is{nondum
Knowledge Point: Tok can have one of three meanings. The meaning `still' is illustrated in~(\ref{exe:tokstill}) above. The meaning `first' is demonstrated in~(\ref{exe:tokfirst}). When tok is combined with a negated verb, it is translated as `yet'. Expressions with the meaning `not yet' are also known as nondums \parencite{vdauwera1998,veselinova2015}. %cf German erst, schon-ernst-noch paper 1989
Content 1: \gll sayang-un \textbf{tok} kalom{\textless}lom{\textgreater}un | \gls nutmeg-3POSS still young{\textless}RED{\textgreater} | \glt `Their nutmeg is still young.'
Content 2: \gll ma \textbf{tok} ecien=i kewe=ko | \gls 3SG first return=PLNK house=LOC | \glt `First he went home.'

Subsubsection: Iamitive se `already' and nondum tok `still; yet; first'\is{iamitive\is{nondum
Knowledge Point: Tok can also be a free-standing negative answer (an \is{interjection}interjection) meaning either `still' or `not yet', depending on whether the question contained a negative or not. Consider the contrast between~(\ref{exe:stillschool}) and~(\ref{exe:notschool}).
Content 1: \gll tok | \gls still | \glt `Yes [I still go to school].'
Content 2: \gll tok | \gls not.yet | \glt `Not yet.'

Subsubsection: Iamitive se `already' and nondum tok `still; yet; first'\is{iamitive\is{nondum
Knowledge Point: (\ref{exe:nakalcatok}) is taken from a story about a black-haired monkey and a white-haired cuscus. The monkey asks the cuscus how to become white-haired. The cuscus then traps the monkey in a narrow cage and puts him in the rising sea, whereupon the monkey sees first his feet, then his belly, and then his entire body become lighter. The first tok in utterance B, an interjection, contrasts with se `already' in utterance A, and hence takes the negative `not yet' meaning. The second tok in answer B is an instance of the aspectual marker, here meaning `still'.
Content 1: Not found

Subsubsection: Iamitive se `already' and nondum tok `still; yet; first'\is{iamitive\is{nondum
Knowledge Point: Iamitive se can often be translated with English `already' or a perfect. In~(\ref{exe:seboet}), the first se acts like a perfect, while the second can be translated as `already'.
Content 1: Not found

Subsubsection: Iamitive se `already' and nondum tok `still; yet; first'\is{iamitive\is{nondum
Knowledge Point: Se is also used to make reference to (cultural) expectations (as is the case in Malay usage/culture, see also \citealt{olsson2013}). One cannot ask `Are you married?' or `Do you have children?' without using se. In Kalamang, since one is expected to marry and reproduce at some point, the use of se reflects this expectation.\footnote{Similar to English `yet'.} Likewise, the answer to these questions cannot be `yes' or `no', but has to be se `already' (plus at least a repetition of the predicate and possibly also including a subject) or tok `not yet'. An example is given in~(\ref{exe:senamgon}).
Content 1: Not found

Subsubsection: Iamitive se `already' and nondum tok `still; yet; first'\is{iamitive\is{nondum
Knowledge Point: These (cultural) expectations are also expressed through se for more everyday situations. In Maas, the village of the speaker in~(\ref{exe:lampurse}), lights are automatically turned on at 5:30PM. By using se with yuol `shine', the speaker expresses that an expected situation has occurred.
Content 1: \gll go se ginggir lampur \textbf{se} yuol | \gls condition IAM late_afternoon lamp IAM shine | \glt `It was late afternoon, the lamps were already on.'

Subsubsection: Iamitive se `already' and nondum tok `still; yet; first'\is{iamitive\is{nondum
Knowledge Point: The iamitive can also be used for changes of state, as in~(\ref{exe:sebotemun}), where a child has grown up in the course of the story.
Content 1: \gll an bo lembaga nerun tumun-an \textbf{se} bo temun | \gls 1SG go cell inside child-1SG.POSS IAM go big | \glt `I went into prison, my child has grown up.'

Subsubsection: Iamitive se `already' and nondum tok `still; yet; first'\is{iamitive\is{nondum
Knowledge Point: Finally, iamitive se occurs in a fixed expression with koyet `to be finished' to indicate the end of a state or event, or of an entire story. (\ref{exe:pakuin}) narrates the building of a house. Se koyet is used to indicate that a day's work is finished. (\ref{exe:maraouk}) is the last utterance in a story about a feast. The last events are listed (the serving and consuming of tea and food), and then the story is closed off with se koyet `the end'.
Content 1: \gll toni eh ma se me \textbf{se} \textbf{koyet} kasur=et eba paku=kin | \gls say hey 3PL IAM DIST IAM finish tomorrow=IRR then nail={\glkin} | \glt `[He] said: ``Hey, that's it, [we're] finished, tomorrow we'll nail.'
Content 2: \gll mu ter=at maraouk muaw=at maraouk in ter-nan=i koyet muap=i koyet \textbf{se} \textbf{koyet} | \gls 3PL tea=OBJ serve food=OBJ serve 1PL.EXCL tea-consume=PLNK finish eat=PLNK finish IAM finish | \glt `They served the tea, served the food, we finished drinking tea, finished eating, the end.'

Subsubsection: Iamitive se `already' and nondum tok `still; yet; first'\is{iamitive\is{nondum
Knowledge Point: The two aspectual markers are compatible with negated or inherently negative verbs (§\ref{sec:lexicalneg}), but change in meaning. The aspectual markers have scope over the negation\is{negation}. The aspectual word tok `still; yet; first' can be combined with a negated predicate to form the meaning `not yet', as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:tokki}) (see also~\ref{exe:toksampi}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll pi taruot=et pi \textbf{tok} sampi=\textbf{nin} | \gls 1PL.INCL speak=IRR 1PL.INCL yet arrive=NEG | \glt `We are talking, we haven't finished yet.'

Subsubsection: Iamitive se `already' and nondum tok `still; yet; first'\is{iamitive\is{nondum
Knowledge Point: When iamitive se is combined with a negative verb or negated predicate, it forms the meaning `not any more'. This is illustrated in example~(\ref{exe:se}).
Content 1: Not found

Subsubsection: Iamitive se `already' and nondum tok `still; yet; first'\is{iamitive\is{nondum
Knowledge Point: The aspectual markers have scope over quantifiers and predicates. Consider (\ref{exe:redai}), where negator =nin has scope over reidak `much' and na `eat', and tok has scope over both. For a further description of the behaviour of quantifiers with respect to the NP and the predicate, see §\ref{sec:nmodqnt}. %This could be an argument for treating those ``object numerals'' that are outside the NP as part of the Predicate or as argument for a VP, but see nmodqnt.
Content 1: \gll ma tok [[\textbf{reidak}-i nat]=\textbf{nin}] | \gls 3SG yet much-OBJQNT consume=NEG | \glt `He hasn't eaten much yet.'

Knowledge Point: The clitic =teba, which attaches to the predicate, expresses progressive or continuous aspect, indicating that an action is incomplete or in progress. Two examples are given in~(\ref{exe:garungdeba}) and~(\ref{exe:repteba}).
Content 1: \gll in bo Esa Tanggiun kai-rep=\textbf{teba} | \gls 1PL.EXCL go Esa Tanggiun firewood-collect={\glteba} | \glt `We went collecting firewood at Esa Tanggiun.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The progressive clitic can also be used with future reference, such as in~(\ref{exe:kanas}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The clitic can be in two different positions in the clause: it can attach directly to the predicate, and then it may be followed by, for example, irrealis =et (as in~\ref{exe:kanas} above) or imperative =te (example~\ref{exe:tebare2}); it can also come in position 8 (Table~\ref{tab:modifiersall}), where it follows volitional =kin or negator =nin (examples~\ref{exe:kindeba} and~\ref{exe:nindebaa}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll bal se koraru se kuet=te nat=kin=\textbf{teba} | \gls dog IAM bite IAM bring={\glte} consume={\glkin}={\glteba} | \glt `The dog has bitten [the fish], has brought [it] and wants to eat [it].'
Content 3: \gll an tok bo mat ketemu=nin=\textbf{teba} | \gls 1SG yet go 3SG.OBJ meet.MLY=NEG={\glteba} | \glt `I have never met him.'

Knowledge Point: The combination of predicate linker =i and the verb koyet `to be finished' expresses completive aspect. The construction is part of a complex predicate also described in §\ref{sec:ikoyetsvc}. Completive =i koyet is only used to link one action to another, and is therefore often best translated as `after'. See also §\ref{sec:tailhead}. (\ref{exe:lemarat}) is taken from a narrative about building a house, and illustrates a typical string of actions linked by =i koyet.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The construction Verb-i koyet can also be a quantifying expression meaning `all; until finished', as described in §\ref{ch:quant}. Completive aspect typically expresses that a totality of referents is affected, which is close in meaning to the quantifying use of -i koyet. However, like other languages in East Indonesia\is{East Indonesian languages}, the completive is used also when an actor deliberately ends an event \parencite{unterladstetter2020}. In~(\ref{exe:lemarat}), there are clear agents, but one could argue that a totality of referents is affected (all the roof wood is installed, the whole roof is closed). In~(\ref{exe:neweri}), however, the referent is firewood, and not all the firewood is bought, and neither is it probable that all the money was spent.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Bisa `can' occurs clause-finally following \is{conditional}conditional markers to express general possibility (example~\ref{exe:bisa0}). After the subject, it expresses possibility or ability (example~\ref{exe:bisa3}). In biclausal conditional clauses, as in example~(\ref{exe:bisa2}), bisa precedes the subject. Bisa also precedes the subject in questions, like~(\ref{exe:bisa2}).
Content 1: \gll jadi ter nan-ere \textbf{bisa} kai nan-ere \textbf{bisa} | \gls so tea consume-{\glcond} can medicine drink-{\glcond} can | \glt `So if [you] drink it as tea that's possible or if [you] drink it as medicine that's possible.'
Content 2: \gll an mat gerket ka \textbf{bisa} nan ye ge | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ ask 2SG can consume or not | \glt `I asked him: ``Can you eat or not?'''

Knowledge Point: Harus `must' expresses necessity, and usually occurs after the subject as in~(\ref{exe:welbon}). Like bisa `can', it precedes the subject in conditional clauses, see~(\ref{exe:watjie}). It is also sometimes used without the predicate it is supposed to modify, presumably when the event to which the main verb refers is clear from the context, as in~(\ref{exe:harus1}).
Content 1: \gll kalau kabor-un nain ko{\textless}yo{\textgreater}yal=te nain=kap=et me \textbf{harus} mu wat jie=ta | \gls if stomach-3POSS like disturbed{\textless}ATTEN{\textgreater}={\glte} like=SIM=IRR TOP must 3PL PROX.OBJ get=NFIN | \glt `If the stomach is like it's disturbed, they have to get this.'
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll kariak sara nakal=ko \textbf{harus} kai_modar | \gls blood ascend head=LOC must marungga_tree | \glt `[If] blood goes up to the head, [you] must [use] marungga tree.'

Knowledge Point: Reon `maybe' expresses uncertainty or possibility and occurs clause-finally with verbal and non-verbal predicates, and modifies the whole clause. An example with a non-verbal predicate is given in~(\ref{exe:reon}).
Content 1: \gll kon siun wilak=ko yuwa \textbf{reon} | \gls one edge sea=LOC PROX maybe | \glt `The one here on the edge on the sea-side maybe?'

Knowledge Point: Gen `maybe' also expresses uncertainty or possibility and follows the subject, as in~(\ref{exe:gen}). Apart from its position in the clause, there is no difference in meaning. Gen, like reon, modifies the entire clause. It is unclear whether gen and reon can co-occur.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The two negative modal markers behave slightly differently. Eranun `cannot' triggers nominalisation of the verb it modifies, and follows that nominalised verb. In a few cases, eranun stands in a clause on its own (following comma intonation\is{intonation}). In that case, the preceding clause has a normal verbal predicate, as in~(\ref{exe:siendaet}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The construction suka-\textsc{poss} \textsc{neg} `not like; not want' usually appears as the only verb-like element in the clause, but must refer to a preceding proposition.\footnote{Suka is likely a nominalised verb or a noun, and hence examples with suka-\textsc{poss} \textsc{neg} could be paraphrased as `is not of subject's liking'.} If combined with a verb in the same clause, the verb is negated with negator =nin, as in~(\ref{exe:amatmu}). The positive counterparts of suka-\textsc{poss} \textsc{neg} `not like; not want' are irrealis marker =kin, which can also be used to express volition, and lo `to want; to consent'. These are described in §\ref{sec:lexicalneg} and~§\ref{sec:kin}.
Content 1: \gll ma se \textbf{suka-un} am=at mu ∅=\textbf{nin} | \gls 3SG IAM want-3POSS breast=OBJ 3PL give=NEG | \glt `She doesn't want to give them breast [milk] any more.'

Knowledge Point: Loi `quickly' is illustrated in~(\ref{exe:loi1}) and~(\ref{exe:loi2}). Though analysed as monomorphemic here, it is likely that the final -i is an instance of predicate linker =i. It can also stand alone as a command (with the imperative clitic: lo=te).
Content 1: \gll kome=i koyet \textbf{loi} eti | \gls look=PLNK finish quickly return | \glt `[When you're] done looking, return quickly.'
Content 2: \gll ka se \textbf{loi} gonggin=et | \gls 2SG IAM quickly know=IRR | \glt `You quickly learn.'

Knowledge Point: The second manner adverbial, dumuni, only has eight occurrences in the corpus, and its semantics are not entirely clear. It is only used with events that express movement, and the use of dumuni seems to indicate a change of direction. This is illustrated in~(\ref{exe:dumuni}) to~(\ref{exe:gontum}). The question marks in the translation lines indicate that I am not sure whether I used the right verb.
Content 1: \gll ma tumun opa me se mengga \textbf{dumuni} ra | \gls 3SG child {\glopa} TOP IAM DIST.LAT MANNER go | \glt `That child already escaped? to there.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The third manner adverbial, sororoi, occurs twice in the corpus, in the same story, to modify the verb bara `descend' in the context of climbing down a tree. The utterance in~(\ref{exe:sororoi}) follows an order made by a giant for the protagonist of the story to come down. It is unclear which exact meaning sororoi adds to the utterance, but speakers have indicated it has to do with manner.
Content 1: \gll ma sororoi bara | \gls 3SG MANNER descend | \glt `She climbed down.'

Knowledge Point: The clitic =sawe(t) usually attaches to predicates in the form of stative verbs, as in~(\ref{exe:sawe}), but can be on any predicate such as the incorporation construction halanganrep `to look for trouble' in~(\ref{exe:sawe2}) or the transitive verb kona `to see' in~(\ref{exe:irulp}).
Content 1: \gll ma ririn=\textbf{sawe} | \gls 3SG tall=too | \glt `It's too tall.'
Content 2: \gll mu me halangan-rep=\textbf{sawe} | \gls 3PL TOP trouble-get=too | \glt `They're looking for too much trouble.'
Content 3: \gll Irul pi mat konan=\textbf{sawe} | \gls Irul 1PL.EXCL 3SG.OBJ see=too | \glt `Irul, we keep on seeing him.'

Knowledge Point: The uses of =tun are illustrated in~(\ref{exe:tuntoo}) and~(\ref{exe:tunvery}). As an intensifier, it attaches only to reduplicated roots. These can be verbs, adverbials, nouns (as in example~\ref{exe:tunvery}) or quantifiers\is{quantifier}.
Content 1: \gll nika kahen=\textbf{tun} ge nika taraman-kodak | \gls fishing_line long=too no fishing_line fathom-just_one | \glt `Not a too long fishing line, just one fathom.'
Content 2: \gll ma siun∼siun=\textbf{tun} timbang-un=ko | \gls 3SG edge∼INTS-INTS forehead-3SG=LOC | \glt `It's at the very edge, at his forehead.'
Content 3: \gll ma siun∼siun=\textbf{tun} timbang-un=ko | \gls 3SG edge∼INTS-INTS forehead-3SG=LOC | \glt `It's at the very edge, at his forehead.'

Knowledge Point: Temporal adverbials set the temporal scene for a clause and modify the entire clause. Temporal adverbials come in the clause-initial (i.e. pre-subject) slot. Examples of temporal adverbials are listed in~(\ref{exe:tempadv}) below.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: An example with wis `yesterday' is given in~(\ref{exe:wis1}), and opa yuwa `(earlier) today' and kasur `tomorrow' are shown in~(\ref{exe:kasur}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: When used adverbially, the times of day always occur at the beginning of the clause, illustrated in~(\ref{exe:godung}). They can be accompanied by bo `go' to create the meaning `when it had turned [part of day]', as in~(\ref{exe:bogosaun}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{go_dung} inier se koi bot | \gls morning 1DU.EX IAM again go | \glt `In the morning we left again.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{bo} \textbf{go.saun} mu se muap=at maraouk | \gls go evening 3PL IAM food=OBJ put_out | \glt `When it turned evening they put out the food.'

Knowledge Point: To make the construction `last/earlier this + part of day' opa `earlier' is used. Opa cannot be combined with (go) dung `(in the) morning', but can be combined with another temporal adverbial, naupar `morning'. The only time of day that retains go in combination with opa is go yuol, perhaps because yuol can also mean `light'. See the overview in~(\ref{exe:partdayopa}) and~(\ref{exe:opasaun}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll \textbf{opa} \textbf{saun} jam tiga an se toni min=kin | \gls last night o'clock three 1SG IAM want sleep={\glkin} | \glt `Last night at three o'clock I wanted to go sleep.'

Knowledge Point: The days of the week are all derived from the Malay terms, which in turn are loans from Arabic. They are usually preceded by the Malay loan hari `day'. The days are listed in~(\ref{exe:weekdays}). The pronunciation roba for `Wednesday' seems to be rather marginal; most people use Malay rabu. An example with ariemun `Friday' is given in~(\ref{exe:ariemun}). Ariemun seems to be a contraction of hari `day' and emun `mother; big' (since Friday is the most important day in Islam) rather than a loan from Malay/Indonesian jumat, ultimately Arabic aljumʕa.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll an toni \textbf{ariemun} eba in tok bo=et | \gls 1SG say Friday then 1PL.EXCL first go=IRR | \glt `I said we wait until Friday and then we go.'

Knowledge Point: The moon phases are designated pak talawak `new moon' and pak tubak `full moon'. Four months from the Arabic calendar with Kalamang names are currently in use in a twelve-month system. They are listed in~(\ref{exe:months}), with the corresponding Malay names and the number of the month in the Arabic calendar. Three of the four month names are derived from nouns that are currently in use in Kalamang. The reason the month known as `safar' in Arabic is derived from Kalamang roba `Wednesday' is that people in Malaysia and parts of Indonesia, including the Karas Islands, celebrate the last bath of the prophet Muhammad by bathing in the sea and having a picnic on the beach on the last Wednesday of that month.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: All `... ago' constructions were elicited. In practice, people prefer to use wis to indicate that the event took place in the past. Like kemarin in Malay, wis can be yesterday, but also any other time before today. To indicate a really long time ago (usually when talking about another generation, or when telling fictional stories), one can use wiseme `a long time ago'. (\ref{exe:wiseme}) is the beginning of a story about the Second World War.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The clitic =taet `more; again', which is attached to the predicate, indicates that the proposition is repeated, continued or extended. It almost invariably co-occurs with koi `again', which is further illustrated below. (\ref{exe:taet1}) and~(\ref{exe:taet2}) show =taet together with koi. In the latter, the meaning conveyed is slightly more that of \is{repetition}repetition than of continuation. %non-verbal examples: koi bolodaet = sedikit lagi, koi reidaktaet = tamba banyak lagi, koi kalistaet = masih hujan lagi, eirtaet, iniertaet
Content 1: \gll ma \textbf{koi} baran=\textbf{taet} | \gls 3SG then descend=more | \glt `Then he goes further down.'
Content 2: \gll ibu nawanggar in \textbf{koi} sanggaran=\textbf{taet} | \gls miss wait 1PL.EXCL again search=again | \glt `Miss waits and we search again.'

Knowledge Point: In a few cases, =taet is also found on pronouns, when the actor is in \is{focus}focus rather than the action. In~(\ref{exe:taet3}), where the speaker and the addressee are taking turns describing objects, the speaker encliticises =taet to the pronoun, because the focus is on who is talking. (Cf. English `Now YOU again speak' vs. `Now you SPEAK again'). Similarly, in~(\ref{exe:andaet}), which is take from a story about a monkey and a cuscus who keep switching places in a boat, the focus is on the pronoun an `I'.
Content 1: \gll ka=\textbf{taet} ewa=te | \gls 2SG=again speak=IMP | \glt `You speak again.'
Content 2: \gll ka me or=ko an=\textbf{taet} bo sabar=et | \gls 2SG TOP stern=LOC 1SG=again go bow=IRR | \glt `You are at the stern, I again go to the bow.'

Knowledge Point: %In example~\ref{exe:taet4} -taet is perhaps suffixed to the number because the clause lacks a verb. Deleted because nubmers can be predicative, as explained under numerals above.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Koi `again' indicates \is{repetition}repetition of an event. Its placement is variable. In~(\ref{exe:koi1}), koi precedes the object and the verb, but in~(\ref{exe:koi2}) it follows the object and precedes the verb. In clauses without object, such as~(\ref{exe:koi3}), koi is between the subject and the verb. Koi always follows aspectual markers se and tok.
Content 1: \gll ma \textbf{koi} kaluar ma \textbf{koi} kiun=at tu | \gls 3SG again exit 3SG again wife.3POSS=OBJ hit | \glt `[If] he goes out again he'll hit his wife again.'
Content 2: \gll an se mat \textbf{koi} pouk | \gls 1SG IAM 3SG.OBJ again carry_on_back | \glt `I carried him on my back again.'
Content 3: \gll go_dung inier se \textbf{koi} bot | \gls morning 1DU.EX IAM again go | \glt `In the morning we left again.'

Knowledge Point: %Koi `then; further' is a conjunction that links sequential actions or events. It follows the subject of the second clause, as illustrated in~\ref{exe:koi0}, which in contrast to~\ref{exe:koi} has an overt subject. It can also link states, as in example~\ref{exe:koi4}, where the speaker summarises the objects he sees in a picture. There, koi `then; further' is combined with comitative =bon. The comitative, marked on each object besides somkon `one person', indicates the three objects are in the same picture as the person. Koi `then; further', mentioned after the first object, indicates the speaker is summarising. Koi is also an adverb meaning `again', see §\ref{sec:taet}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The clitic occurs several times on the manner \is{demonstrative!manner}demonstratives wandi `like this' and mindi `like that' (the latter is illustrated in example~\ref{exe:keweneko}), following similative marker =kap (example~\ref{exe:rombon}), and on the question word tamandi `how' (example~\ref{exe:manditen}). Another example, on the verb pue `to hit', is given in~(\ref{exe:purenme}). An analysis that might fit for part of the data, represented by these examples, is that of a subordinate clause marker, expressing meanings like `since', `as' or `after'. This potential reading is indicated in brackets in the translation. If this analysis is correct, the relativiser use of =ten is a specific example of this more general use.
Content 1: \gll an kewe neko=et me \textbf{mindi=ten} me eranun | \gls 1SG house inside=IRR TOP like_that=TEN TOP cannot | \glt `If I'm in the house (as it is like that) I can't do it.
Content 2: \gll in opa rombongan baran=\textbf{ten=kap} me tengguen=i koyet in se mengga kubirar=ka bot | \gls 1PL.EXCL {\glopa} group descend=TEN=SIM TOP gather=PLNK finish 1PL.EXCL IAM DIST.LAT graveyard=LAT go | \glt `(When) we, that group, moved down, had all gathered, we went from there to the graveyard.'
Content 3: \gll kaden-un metko pue=\textbf{ten} me supaya tu=te di=metko=et bisa balama=te mindi naladur=et bisa | \gls body-3POSS DIST.LOC hit=TEN TOP so_that hit={\glte} CAUS=DIST.LOC=IRR can heat_in_fire={\glte} like_that massage=IRR can | \glt `(When?) [you] hit the body there, so that hitting and putting it there is possible, and heating in the fire and massaging is possible.'

Knowledge Point: %\textit{(Harald: ``the first two look like you might have the `topic as conditional' construction and since \ref{exe:minditenme} has -ten in the apodosis too maybe you are dealing with a construction for `If X is Z, Y is likewise Z' expressed as `If X being Z like that, Y being also Z'.'' This seems to make sense when I apply this hypothesis to the other corpus examples, too.)}
